text:
Broad Street, east side, from Exchange Place to Wall Street (left), showing prominently the massive Mills Bldg. Adjoining same on the far side is the Drexel, Morgan Bldg. The open street in the foreground is the well known Curb Market. Note the U. S. Sub-treasury at the extreme left. This photo is an enlargement from an original lantern slide.

Circa 1890

Gift of Russell Freeman
New York Public Library

Broad Street, east side, north across Exchange Place, to show prominently the Mills Building and it's adjoining Drexel Morgan & Co. structure. The latter is at Wall Street, where appears the Colonial U. S. Sub Treasury. Beyond that point, this thoroughfare continues as Nassau Street. The New York Stock Exchange is on the right, tho not included in this view. The massive Mills Building was erected in the 1880's and removed in 1926 for the 38 story Equitable Trust Building.

About 1890-5

J. S. Johnston, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

Broad Street, north from and including Exchange Place, to and including Wall Street. Also shown is Nassau Street, (a continuation of Broad Street, north of Wall Street) west side, north from and including Wall, to and including Pine Streets. The view also shows a portion of the United States Sub Treasury Building, in the background, at the N.E. corner of Wall and Nassau Streets.

About 1893.

Brown Brothers.

Broad Street, at Exchange Place, viewing northward towards Wall Street, showing the curb market in action. Progressively on the left appear the Wall Street Journal, Ocean Cables, Johnstone (clock outside), Blair, Commercial Cables, N. Y. Stock Exchange, Gillenden, Hanover National Bank and Bank of Commerce (over top of the Subtreasury) Buildings continuing on the right to the margin are the Drexel, Mills and the Broad Exchange Buildings.

Early 1900's

Thomas W. Kennedy Collection
Gift of the Museum Photographer's Association
Thru Beecher Ogden

Broad Street, north across Exchange Place, showing the Curb Market in action. The various brokers and traders transact their business in the street and signal results to their office associates in the fore ground buildings. Subsequently they will erect a building to house this exchange. At the left are, the Johnston, Blair, Mackay, N. Y. Stock Exchange, Gillenden, and Hanover Trust Bldgs. View 2 eliminates the first mentioned structure and includes a glimpse of the U. S. Sub Treasury on the right.

About 1900's
October 1904

Thomas W. Kennedy, photo
Thru Beecher Ogden
Museum Photographers Assn.

George L. Balgue, photo

Broad Street, north across Exchange Place, showing the Curb Market in action. The various brokers and traders transact their business in the street and signal results to their office associates in the fore ground buildings. Subsequently they will erect a building to house this exchange. At the left are, the Johnston, Blair, Mackay, N. Y. Stock Exchange, Gillenden, and Hanover Trust Bldgs. View 2 eliminates the first mentioned structure and includes a glimpse of the U. S. Sub Treasury on the right.

About 1900's
October 1904

Thomas W. Kennedy, photo
Thru Beecher Ogden
Museum Photographers Assn.

George L. Balgue, photo

Broad Street, north from a point between Beaver St. and Exchange Place, and across the latter to Wall Street. Both of these views show the curb market that operates here below Exchange Place. To the left are a number of prominent structures, that are progressively, the Johnston, Blair, Mackay, N. Y. Stock Exchange, Wilks, Gillenden and Hanover Trust Buildings. View 2 is identical, with the exception of the obvious replacement of the Gillenden by the Bankers Trust Bldg. Note the glimpse of the U. S. Sub Treasury shown.

No. 1: April 1906
2: 1911

George L. Balgue

Broad Street, north from a point between Beaver St. and Exchange Place, and across the latter to Wall Street. Both of these views show the curb market that operates here below Exchange Place. To the left are a number of prominent structures, that are progressively, the Johnston, Blair, Mackay, N. Y. Stock Exchange, Wilks, Gillenden and Hanover Trust Buildings. View 2 is identical, with the exception of the obvious replacement of the Gillenden by the Bankers Trust Bldg. Note the glimpse of the U. S. Sub Treasury shown.

No. 1: April 1906
2: 1911

George L. Balgue

Broad Street from and including Exchange Place to and including Wall Street, also showing 1-27 Nassau Street, west side, from Wall to Cedar Streets. On the right, the buildings are: The Mills Building, the Drexel, Morgan & Company Buildings and the United States Sub-Treasury Building, on Wall Street on the site of Federal Hall. On the left, with the columns, is the New York Stock Exchange. On the street, in the foreground, is the Curb Exchange. This exchange met in the street before its building was erected.

About 1895.

Wurts Brothers.

Broad Street, west side, north from Exchange Place, across Wall Street, to Pine Street. Progressively shown are five structures that are identified as the, Blair, Mackay, New York Stock Exchange, Wilks, Bankers Trust (under construction) and the Hanover National Bank buildings.

1911

Gift of Urbrock Collection

Broad Street, east side, north from and including Exchange Place, to and including Wall Street.
About 1914.

Brown Brothers.

23-11 Broad Street, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of Exchange Place.
About 1922.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

30-36 Broad Street, at the S.W. corner of Exchange Place.
About 1925.

Edwin Levick.

Broad Street from and including Exchange Place to and including Wall Street, also showing the west side of Nassau Street from Wall to Cedar Streets. In the centre, the 38-story Equitable Trust Company Building is being erected on the site of the old Mills Building, built in the 1880's. Above it, on Wall Street, is the Sub-Treasury Building, built in 1842 on the site of the old Federal Hall, where the Federal Government of the United States was inaugurated and George Washington inducted as the nation's first president. In the left background may be seen the New York Stock Exchange, on the S.W. corner of Broad and Wall Streets. Across from it between the Equitable Trust excavation and the Sub-Treasury, is the building of J.P. Morgan & Company.

1926.

Brown Brothers.

Broad Street, west side, north from but not including Exchange Place, to and including Wall Street. The view also shows Nassau Street, (a continuation of Broad Street, north of Wall Street) west side, north from and including Wall Street, to, but not including Maiden Lane.

About August 1926.

Brown Brothers.

Broad Street, north from and including Exchange Place, to and including Wall Street. The small building shown in the background, is the U.S. Sub Treasury, at the N.E. corner of Broad and Wall Streets.

About 1927.

N. Y. Edison Co.

(1)
23 to 1 Broad Street, east side, north from Exchange Place (right) to Wall Street, showing the lower stories of the 38 story Equitable Building, No. 11-23, at the N.E. corner of Exchange Place. The low structure adjacent to same is the J. P. Morgan & Co. Building and bears No. 1-9. The latter is at the S.E. corner of Wall Street. Partially shown on the extreme right is the 21 story Broad Exchange Building, No. 25-33, at the S.E. corner of Exchange Place.

P. L. Sperr.

September 16, 1931.

(2)
The same, showing only the upper portions of buildings concerned. Across the background appear the Bank of Manhattan and the 60 Wall Tower. The latter uncompleted.

P. L. Sperr.

September 16, 1931.

25-33 Broad Street, at the S.E. corner of Exchange Place, seen from New Street across the site of the Johnston Building, which has just been demolished.

July 26, 1931.

P.L. Sperr.

The Broad Exchange Bldg.

26-18 Broad Street, at, adjoining, and north of the N.W. corner of Exchange Place, seen across the site of the recently demolished Johnston Building.

July 26, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

26-60 Broad Street, from Exchange Place to north of Beaver Street. In the foreground, the Johnston Building is being demolished.

July 4, 1931.

P.L. Sperr.

Forty-eight-story skyscraper, which is being erected on Broad Street, Exchange Place and New Street for the Continental Bank, the "Margin Reservoir".
Jul 23 1931
Forty-eight-story building for the Continental Bank and Trust Company under construction at 30 Broad Street, the site of the Old Johnston Bldg.

Broad Street looking north from the Western Union Building. 40 Broad Street. View of Broad Street at 6 o'clock PM. When Moranti & Raymond the contractors, open the street for all night construction, restoring the planking for traffic by 8 A.M.
